Column Comment.0: EQUIPMENT CATALOGUE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the list of kinds ofequipment. Think of this as a catalogue or brochure that shows all the kinds ofequipment that you may use, but may or may not actually have. Actual peices ofequipment that exist are defined in the table EQUIPMENT.
Column Comment.1: SPECIFICATION IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a specification measured for apeice of equipment.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: AVERAGE VALUE: The average or single value assigned to this specification. If onlyone mesuare is provided, it should be stored here.
Column Comment.6: COST: A value associated with the cost of a specirfication, such as annual operatingcost.
Column Comment.7: CURRENCY CONVERSION: A number which, when multipled by the stored value,will re-create the original value in the original currency used.
Column Comment.8: CURRENCY ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: The units of measure in which thecurrency was originally received.
Column Comment.10: DATE FORMAT DESCRIPTION: Use this column to define the level of precision inthe DATE format colums, such as YYYY, or YYYQQ, or YYYYMM or YYYYMMDD
Column Comment.11: EFFECTIVE DATE: date on which the data in this row came into effect.
Column Comment.12: EXPIRY DATE: Date on which the data in this row of data was no longer in effect.
Column Comment.13: MAXIMUM DATE: the maximum date, such as an expiry date, that describes thisproduct.
Column Comment.14: MAXIMUM VALUE: the maximum value for a specification, such as the maximumdiameter of a tank, or the maximum load capacity of a vehicle.
Column Comment.17: MINUMUM DATE: the minimum date associated with a specification, such as a datethat a product cannot be used for, such as for aging processes.
Column Comment.18: MINIMUM VALUE: the minimum value associated with a specification, such asminimum pipe thickness or minimum pressure capability.
Column Comment.21: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.22: REFERENCE VALUE: the value of a reference point. For example where theequipment is a tank for which tank strappings are measured, the reference pointwould be the height measurement in the tank. The volume measure at the referencetank strapping will usually be captured in AVERAGE VALUE. Other reference values,such as pressures or temperatures that reference specifications are also permitted.
Column Comment.24: EQUIPMENT SPECIFICATION REFERENCE TYPE: Use this table to indicate thekind of referece point used to describe specifications. For example, if thespecifications being captured are tank strappings, the SPEC TYPE = TANKSTRAPPING and SPEC REF TYPE = STRAPPING MARKERS and theREFERENCED VALUE = the height measure on the tank.
Column Comment.26: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.27: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.28: SPECIFICATION CODE: a descriptive code allowed for a particular kind ofspecificaiton. For example, For Rock bit classificaitons, the IADC rock bitclassification code designates feature descriptions using codes from 1 - 7.
Column Comment.29: SPECIFICATION DESCRIPTION: A textual description of the specification property.
Column Comment.30: SPECIFICATION TYPE: The type of specification, such as diameter, strength, length,resonating frequency etc.
Column Comment.31: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.32: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.33: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.34: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.35: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.36: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.37: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
